column3: str

Vuyargur would see the workers take their scheduled break. 

※Please note that the difficulty of this quest has been synced to your current level. Furthermore, you may not proceed with a class or job that is different from when you accepted this quest.

With the chat mode in <UIForeground>F201F4</UIForeground><UIGlow>F201F5</UIGlow>Say<UIGlow>01</UIGlow><UIForeground>01</UIForeground>, enter “The chairo is ready” to encourage the Yok Huy in the Shades of Grief to take a break.
Speak with Vuyargur.

Late again... <sigh> Oh, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>. Some workers gathering materials in the Shades of Grief have yet to return for their break. I have impressed upon them the importance of regularly scheduled rest for overall productivity, and yet!
As an added incentive, I have prepared a fresh batch of chairo, a warming stew much loved in these parts. I suspect a hot meal will make them forget their tasks for a few brief moments.
Could I trouble you to visit the Shades of Grief and inform them that the chairo is ready?
The chairo is ready
Must...get...more stone...!

With the chat mode in <UIForeground>F201F4</UIForeground><UIGlow>F201F5</UIGlow>Say<UIGlow>01</UIGlow><UIForeground>01</UIForeground>, use your keyboard or the software keyboard to enter “The chairo is ready” to grab the Yok Huy's attention.
Did someone say chairo?
My favorite! We Yok Huy can't get enough of the stuff. If you cut me open, I daresay I'd bleed chairo!
I must return while the pot is warm. My thanks, friend!
Ow-ow-ow, my back...! Still, I must press on...!
Uwah! I near jumped out of my skin...
I-I mean...ahem. Apologies, I did not notice you approach. Did I hear you mention chairo?
Why, it is long past time for my break! And I shall feel all the more rested after a hot meal.
With Nopli providing us with so many different ingredients and spices as of late, people have been experimenting with new chairo recipes. I wonder what's stewing today!
My thanks for passing along the message. Both workers returned safe and sound and are presently enjoying a well-earned repast.

The restoration is arduous work, to be sure, and they are wont to overexert themselves. Though my chairo started as a simple way to encourage more regular breaks, I must say it has turned into quite the culinary adventure...

Of late, I have been experimenting with different meats and spices to create the most rejuvenating meal possible. Several have proved quite a hit with the workers—at this rate, I'll be opening my own eatery!
Even so, I suspect our workers may continue to neglect their breaks without someone to remind them. I hope I may count on your help in rounding them up again!
